explanation:
Reason 1: Marco Rubio was a U.S. Senator from 2011 to 2017, not a state senator or governor. As such, he would not have had the authority to directly insert anything into any state budget. 

Reason 2: The role of U.S. Congress is to create federal legislation, not state legislation. Any money allocated to states is typically done so in accordance with existing federal laws and regulations. 

Reason 3: Though Congress can allocate money to states in the form of grants, it highly unlikely that Senator Rubio was in any way instrumental in allocating $1.5 million to a single rowing institute. text: Marco Rubio tried to insert $1.5 million for a rowing institute into the state budget.
explanation:
The following statement, that Marco Rubio tried to insert $1.5 million for a rowing institute into the state budget, is a Pants-fire according to CNN.

The first reason this statement is Pants-fire is that Marco Rubio was the speaker of the Florida House of Representatives in 2007 and had no power to add or remove funding to the budget. It is undisputable that the Speaker of the House cannot insert funding for a specific program into the state budget. It is the job of the Legislature to vote on the budget. Another reason this statement is Pants-fire is that Marco Rubio never proposed a budget amendment for the rowing institute. A budget amendment is a proposed alteration to the existing budget that is voted on by the Legislature. A search of the official record of the Florida House of Representatives for a budget amendment to fund the rowing institute did not yield any results. Finally, the statement neglects to mention that the rowing institute funding was actually proposed by State Senator Don Gaetz. In 2007, Gaetz proposed a bill that called for $1.5 million in funding to construct and establish the rowing institute while Rubio was Speaker of the House. This bill was ultimately passed by the Legislature and signed into law. Therefore, according to the facts, this statement is Pants-fire.
